description: From Middle English tupe (compare Scots tuip), origin unknown.

examples: ... to tie up rams, which could not be supposed to much used to handling ... having often heard for a proverb, as mad as a tup in an halter

entries.meaning: The head of a hammer, and particularly of a steam-driven hammer.
examples: Those familiar with drop forging are accustomed to sizing drop hammers as 1 ton or 5 ton or whatever. This measure of the size is simply the weight of the tup. The total weight of the helve of No 2 is about 6.4 tons.

verbs.description: tup (third-person singular simple present tups, present participle tupping, simple past and past participle tupped)

entries.meaning: To mate; used of a ram mating with a ewe.
examples: Even now, now, very now, an old black ram is tupping your white ewe.

entries.meaning: (slang) To have sex with, to bonk, etc.
examples: I love her well enough to tup her, I suppose. A dangerous bit of business, that. She is as fertile as a bloody alluvial plain.

entries.meaning: (regional English, slang) To butt: said of a ram.
